column1: #Text=# Meta Transfer Learning for Early Success Prediction in MOOCs

#Text=This repository is the official implementation of the L@S 2022 Paper entitled ["Meta Transfer Learning for Early Success Prediction in MOOCs"](https://arxiv.org/pdf/2205.01064.pdf) written by [Vinitra Swamy](http://github.com/vinitra), [Mirko Marras](https://www.mirkomarras.com/), and [Tanja K채ser](https://people.epfl.ch/tanja.kaeser/?

column1: #Text=Experiments are located in `scripts/`, corresponding directly to the experimental methodology mentioned in the paper.
#Text=At the beginning of each script, you will find the research question this experiment targets and a short objective statement regarding the model the script generates.
#Text=For more information about each experiment, please reference the paper directly.
#Text=The best behavior-only (`BO`), behavior-timewise-meta (`BTM`), and behavior-static-meta (`BSM`) models for each early prediction setting (40% and 60%) can be found in `models/`.
#Text=These models can be used to warm-start downstream student performance predictions for new or ongoing courses.

#Text=Extract relevant features sets (`BouroujeniEtAl`, `MarrasEtAl`, `LalleConati`, and `ChenCui`) through our lab's EDM 2021 contribution on [benchmarks for feature predictive power](https://github.com/epfl-ml4ed/flipped-classroom).
#Text=Place the results of these feature extraction scripts in `data/`.
#Text=A toy course example of extracted features is included in the `data/` folder.
#Text=Fill out the `data/metadata.csv` file with relevant meta information about your course(s).
#Text=One example of course metadata is currently showcased in the file.
#Text=This information is necessary for extracting the meta features in the BTM and BSM models.
#Text=Run your desired experiment from `scripts/` by executing the script with Python 3.7 or higher.
#Text=We present three model architectures to predict early pass / fail student performance prediction.
#Text=The features used as input to each of these models is truncated to 40% or 60% of the duration of a course, in order to simulate downstream intervention for an ongoing course
#Text=- **Behavior Only** (`BO`): Models trained only using features about student behavior.
#Text=- **Behavior + Time-wise Meta** (`BTM`): Models trained using behavior features and meta features, combined at each timestep and used together as model input.
#Text=- **Behavior + Static Meta** (`BSM`): Models trained using behavior and meta features, combined statically at different layers of the model with attention and projection.

#Text=The best models of each architecture for the two early prediction levels (40% and 60%) are showcased in the `models/` folder, and can be produced with the `BO_Nto1_Diff.py`, `BSM_Nto1_Diff.py`, and `BTM_Nto1_Diff.py` scripts respectively.
#Text=You can load a model and compute predictions (inference) with the following code snippet:
#Text=We extensively evaluate our models on a large data set including 26 MOOCs and 145,714 students in total, with millions of student interactions.
#Text=With our analyses, we target the following three research questions, addressed through experiments in this repository:
#Text=- **RQ 1: Can student behavior transfer across iterations of the same course and across different courses?
#Text=  - `BO_1to1.py`: Train a model on one course's behavior features (behavior-only) and predicting on one course's behavior features
#Text=- `BO_Nto1_Diff.py`: Train a model on N courses' behavior features (behavior-only) and predicting on one course's (or multiple held out courses') behavior features
#Text=- `BO_Nto1_Same.py`: Train a model on behavior features (behavior-only) from previous iterations of a course and predict on behavior features from that course's current iteration
#Text=- **RQ 2: Is a meta learning model trained on a combination of behavior and course metadata information more transferable?
#Text=  - `BSM_Nto1_Diff.py`: Train a model on behavior and meta features from N courses, combined statically (with attention and projection), predict on one course (or multiple hold-out courses).
#Text=This script produces the final architecture, using FastText encoding
#Text=- `BTM_Nto1_Diff.py`: Train a model on behavior and meta features from N courses, combined at each timestep, predict on one course (or multiple hold-out courses)
#Text=- **Encoding experiments**: encoding the course title and description text using different encoders
#Text=- `BTM_Nto1_Diff_FastText.py`: Encode textual meta features with FastText, in a BTM model
#Text=- `BTM_Nto1_Diff_SentenceBERT.py`: Encode textual meta features with SentenceBERT, in a BTM model
#Text=- `BTM_Nto1_Diff_UniversalSentEncoder.py`: Encode textual meta features with SentenceBERT, in a BTM model
#Text=- **RQ 3: Can fine-tuning a combined model on past iterations of an unseen course lead to better transferable models?
#Text=  - `BO_Nto1_Diff_Finetune.py`: Finetune the model trained in `BO_Nto1_Diff.py` on one course
#Text=- `BO_NtoC_Diff_Finetune.py`: Finetune the model trained in `BO_Nto1_Diff.py` on previous iterations of a course, predict on current iteration
#Text=- `BSM_NtoC_Diff_Finetune.py`: Finetune the model trained in `BSM_Nto1_Diff.py` on previous iterations of a course, predict on current iteration
#Text=- `BTM_NtoC_Diff_Finetune.py`: Finetune the model trained in `BTM_Nto1_Diff.py` on previous iterations of a course, predict on current iteration
#Text=  - `predict_on_all_students.py`: Evaluate a trained model on all students, not just the subset of hard students.
#Text=This code can produce the results showcased in Figure 4
#Text=- `rnn_models.py`: Bi-LSTM model architectures used in BO and BTM experiments.
#Text=This code is provided for educational purposes and aims to facilitate reproduction of our results, and further research
#Text=We have done our best to document, refactor, and test the code before publication.
#Text=If you find any bugs or would like to contribute new models, training protocols, etc, please let us know.
#Text=Feel free to file issues and pull requests on the repo and we will address them as we can.
#Text=If you find this code useful in your work, please cite our paper:
#Text=Meta Transfer Learning for Early Success Prediction in MOOCs.
#Text=In: Proceedings of the 2022 ACM Conference on Learning at Scale (L@S 2022).
#Text=This code is free software: you can redistribute it and/or modify it under the terms of the [MIT License](LICENSE).
#Text=This software is distributed in the hope that it will be useful, but without any warranty; without even the implied warranty of merchantability or fitness for a particular purpose.
